title: Steve Kerr is taking a leave of absence to continue rehab on his back
text:
For anyone on or around the Golden State Warriors, the summer of 2015 will be forever remembered as a three-month long celebration.
Championships always seem to have that kind of effect, especially when the organization that wins it all had gone three decades since winning its last.
USA TODAY
Warriors should be favored to win title again
But that was the never the case for Warriors coach Steve Kerr, who dealt with constant back pain after enduring two surgeries and decided on Thursday to take an indefinite leave of absence to recover. Highly-regarded assistant coach Luke Walton will fill his seat while he is out, and only time will tell whether Warriors fans should be concerned about the prospect of having someone of his relative inexperience at the helm. For all we know, Kerr could be back in no time. Or, perhaps, not.
This much is safe to say: the Warriors sure do miss former Warriors associate head coach/New Orleans Pelicans head coach Alvin Gentry right about now. Make no mistake, though, Walton's imprint on this group - which I chronicled during the Finals - has been significant. Kerr, in fact, thought so highly of Walton's candid insights and acumen last season that he made his mantra - "When we don't do stupid (expletive), we're really (expletive) good." - a theme of sorts down the stretch. And in this particular scenario, Kerr clearly saw the notion of suffering through the back pain as, well, stupid.
Kerr isn’t the complaining sort, so it spoke volumes when he showed up at Las Vegas summer league in July with the kind of grimace and gait that made it abundantly clear that he was miserable. I spoke with his wife, Margot, at the time, saying hello briefly while asking if they had been enjoying the glow and shine of their memorable moment. She shook her head and frowned. Kerr’s back situation, quite clearly, was a bigger deal than most had realized.
USA TODAY
Andre Iguodala says he's OK with being the Warriors' Sixth Man
Kerr spoke about his back on Tuesday at the team’s practice facility, when I asked if the experience with his back had taken any of the fun out of his championship summer.
“It took all of the fun out of the summer,” Kerr conceded. “Yeah. I did not have any fun over the summer, which is unfortunate given that we just won the damned title. I was looking forward to a lot of fun, but it’s all part of it and I’ll be ok.”
If not now, apparently, then in due time.
“At this point, the most important thing is to make sure Steve is healthy, completely recovered and ready for not only the rigors of a long NBA season, but day-to-day life in general,” Warriors General Manager Bob Myers in the team's statement. “We don’t anticipate the recovery process will be long term, but as of today we don’t know the exact timeframe. We’ll evaluate his progress daily and provide updates as necessary.”
